content: This article **needs additional citations for verification**. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Havelock Constituency" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(December 2020)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **Havelock Constituency** was a constituency in Singapore. It used to exist from 1955 to 1984. ## History In 1963, [Loh Miaw Gong](/wiki/Loh_Miaw_Gong) was elected as assemblyman for the [Legislative Assembly of Singapore](/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Singapore). However she was arrested under the [Internal Security Act](/wiki/Internal_Security_Act_(Singapore)) before she can assume her seat. In 1967, Loh resigned her seat, along with four other [Barisan Sosialis](/wiki/Barisan_Sosialis) MP. A by-election was called in 1967 to fill in the seat. In 1984, Havelock was merged with nearby constituencies, [Telok Ayer](/wiki/Telok_Ayer_Constituency) and [Kreta Ayer Constituencies](/wiki/Kreta_Ayer_Constituency). ## Member of Parliament **Election** **Member of Parliament****Party**[Legislative Assembly of Singapore](/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Singapore)**1955**[Lim Yew Hock](/wiki/Lim_Yew_Hock)[LF](/wiki/Labour_Front)**1959**Peter Lau Por Tuck[PAP](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party)**1963**[Loh Miaw Gong](/wiki/Loh_Miaw_Gong)[BS](/wiki/Barisan_Sosialis)[Parliament of Singapore](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore)**(/wiki/1963_Singaporean_general_election)**[Loh Miaw Gong](/wiki/Loh_Miaw_Gong) (resigned in 1967) [BS](/wiki/Barisan_Sosialis)**(/wiki/1967_Singaporean_by-elections)**Lim Soo Peng[PAP](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party)**(/wiki/1968_Singaporean_general_election)****(/wiki/1970_Singaporean_by-elections)**[Hon Sui Sen](/wiki/Hon_Sui_Sen)**(/wiki/1972_Singaporean_general_election)****(/wiki/1976_Singaporean_general_election)****(/wiki/1980_Singaporean_general_election)** ## Electoral results Note: The [Elections Department](/wiki/Elections_Department_Singapore) does not include rejected votes when calculating the vote shares of candidates. Hence, all candidates' vote shares will total to 100% at any given election (may not appear so in multi-way contests due to rounding). ### Elections in 1950s [General Election
